title: 105_hr1398
content: The "Parkinson's Research Act of 1997" aims to expand federal investment in Parkinson's research and improve coordination among National Institutes of Health research institutes. It also seeks to enhance care and assistance for individuals with Parkinson's and their family caregivers. The Director of NIH will establish a program for Parkinson's disease research and training, subject to available funds. Coordination among national research institutes conducting Parkinson's research will be ensured, including holding research planning conferences every two years. The Director of NIH will award Core Center Grants to establish Morris K. Udall Research Centers for Parkinson's disease research and training. Each center funded will focus on innovative multidisciplinary research and training related to Parkinson's disease. Each center funded under this subsection must use the facilities of a single institution or consortium, meet qualifications set by the NIH Director, and conduct basic and clinical research. For Parkinson's, centers may also offer training programs for scientists and health professionals, provide information and education to health professionals, and run programs for the community. The center funded under this subsection conducts programs for the dissemination of information to the public, establishes a nationwide data system for Parkinson's patients, and sets up a Parkinson's Disease Information Clearinghouse to enhance understanding of the disease. The center funded under this subsection conducts programs to disseminate information to the public, establish a nationwide data system for Parkinson's patients, and set up a Parkinson's Disease Information Clearinghouse. It also aims to enhance knowledge and understanding of Parkinson's disease through a national education program and provide stipends for scientists and health professionals in training programs. Support for a center may last up to five years, with possible extensions by the Director of NIH. The Director of NIH may extend the period of funding for a center for up to five years based on a peer review recommendation. Additionally, a grant program will be established to support researchers in Parkinson's disease research for a maximum of five years. Authorization of appropriations for Parkinson's disease research is limited to $100,000,000 for fiscal year 1998, with additional funding as needed for 1999 and 2000. Funds cannot be used for research involving human fetal tissue from induced abortions for Parkinson's therapy, except for tissue from spontaneous abortions or ectopic pregnancies.
